G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The best interests of the child are the “paramount concern” of the Court in custody and parenting‑time determinations.

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a court may modify an existing custody or parenting‑time order upon a showing of (a) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (b) that modification is necessary in the best interests of the child.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.support_reasoning: This decision is an appeal from an initial custody judgment and concerns the adequacy of findings regarding domestic violence and its impact on the child. It does not discuss or apply the standard for *modifying* an existing custody or parenting‑time order, nor does it articulate a requirement of a material and substantial change in circumstances since a prior judgment. The opinion instead focuses on best‑interests analysis and the need for explicit findings about domestic violence, so it does not provide authority for the modification standard stated in the proposition.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.relevant_excerpt: "Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31. We do not by this decision require the judge to hear further testimony if he does not consider that necessary, but at the least he must hear both parties and make explicit findings on the matters set out above."

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734, 738 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a court may modify an existing custody or parenting‑time order upon a showing of (a) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (b) that modification is necessary in the best interests of the child.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states the statutory standard under G.L. c. 208, § 28 for modifying custody orders: the judge must find both (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances and (2) that modification is necessary in the best interests of the children. The court then applies that two‑part test to the facts (finding a material change in the mother’s recovery from substance abuse and focusing on best‑interests in evaluating the split‑custody order), squarely supporting the proposition as a correct statement of Massachusetts law.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1993, c. 460, enables a Probate Court judge, upon finding that ‘a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred’ to modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody arrangements of minor children, where the modification ‘is necessary in the best interests of the children.’ … When determining child custody awards in general, or modifications of custody awards based on changed circumstances, the guiding principle always has been the best interests of the children.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.proposition: The best interests of the child are the “paramount concern” of the Court in custody and parenting‑time determinations.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly situates its analysis within the longstanding Massachusetts rule that custody and visitation are governed by the best interests of the child, citing prior cases that describe those best interests as the ‘paramount concern.’ Although the “paramount concern” phrasing is quoted from Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, the court in Kali adopts and reaffirms that principle as the controlling standard for custody and visitation determinations under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a). Thus, the case supports the proposition that best interests are the court’s paramount concern in custody/parenting‑time decisions.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 657 (2002)…; Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’); Surrender of Minor Children, 344 Mass. 230, 234 (1962)… (‘most fundamental [principle] is that the paramount issue is the welfare of the child’).”

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.proposition: The best interests of the child are the “paramount concern” of the Court in custody and parenting‑time determinations.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly applies and discusses the "best interests of the child" standard in the context of adoption and custody, but it does not characterize those best interests as the Court’s "paramount concern" or otherwise use that terminology. The case affirms that best interests is the governing, flexible standard and that trial judges receive substantial deference, yet it stops short of elevating it expressly to a "paramount" concern. Therefore, citing this case specifically for the quoted "paramount concern" formulation is inaccurate.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.relevant_excerpt: Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The “best interests of a child” is a question that presents the trial judge “with a classic example of a discretionary decision.”

Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 191\.proposition: A material and substantial change in circumstances may include changes in a parent’s stability, employment, housing, and ability to care for the child, as well as the child’s age, developmental needs, and expressed preferences.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 191\.support_reasoning: The opinion does mention the statutory standard that custody may be modified upon a material and substantial change in circumstances and that the modification must be in the child’s best interests, but it does not elaborate on what types of changes qualify. It does not discuss changes in a parent’s stability, employment, housing, caregiving ability, or the child’s age, developmental needs, or preferences as examples of such changes. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the specific, detailed list in the claimed proposition.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 191\.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding ‘that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[].’ … However, we shall not sustain an award of custody ‘unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed.’”

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 547\u2.proposition: A material and substantial change in circumstances may include changes in a parent’s stability, employment, housing, and ability to care for the child, as well as the child’s age, developmental needs, and expressed preferences.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 547\u2.support_reasoning: The excerpt is a concurrence focused on statutory interpretation of the paternity statute and the limits of a judge’s authority to order a relocating, sole-legal-parent mother to return. It does not address modification standards or define what constitutes a “material and substantial change in circumstances,” nor does it discuss changes in parental stability, employment, housing, caregiving ability, the child’s age, developmental needs, or expressed preferences as modification factors. The case is about relocation and the legal status of nonmarital parents, not about the modification-change-in-circumstances standard described in the proposition.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 547\u2.relevant_excerpt: “After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not *558disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843 (2003) (‘If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement…’).”}

Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.raw_text: Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865, 870–71 (2006)
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.proposition: A material and substantial change in circumstances may include changes in a parent’s stability, employment, housing, and ability to care for the child, as well as the child’s age, developmental needs, and expressed preferences.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses what qualifies as a "material and substantial change in circumstances" only in a narrow way: it corrects the trial judge and holds that the mother’s post‑divorce remarriage is itself a material and substantial change. It does not address changes in employment, housing, parental stability, ability to care for the child, or the child’s age, developmental needs, or preferences as components of the material-change standard. Those broader factors appear only in the Yannas best‑interests/removal analysis, not in a § 28 material‑change discussion, so the case does not support the full proposition as stated.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.relevant_excerpt: “He concluded from this that any change in circumstances occurred prior to the divorce, and therefore did not justify a modification. His ruling is inconsistent with G. L. c. 208, § 28… ‘[u]pon a complaint after a divorce… the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment… provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred….’ … In the present case, the mother’s marriage is plainly a material and substantial change in circumstances occurring subsequent to the date of divorce.”

Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.raw_text: Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 243–44 (2000)
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.proposition: The Court may consider the child’s preferences, particularly as the child grows older and more mature, as one factor in the best‑interests analysis.
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the best‑interests standard and the wide range of factors a judge may consider, but it does not mention or analyze the child’s own custodial preferences at all. There is no reference to the child’s wishes, maturity, or age as a factor, so this case cannot be cited as authority for considering a child’s preferences in the best‑interests analysis.
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.relevant_excerpt: “[C]ustody orders and judgments…are made on the basis of a determination of the best interests of the child… and a judge may consider any factors found pertinent to those interests in the circumstances of the dispute.” (50 Mass. App. Ct. at 243). [Note: the opinion contains no discussion of the child’s stated preferences.]

Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406, 409\u2.proposition: The Court may consider the child’s preferences, particularly as the child grows older and more mature, as one factor in the best‑interests analysis.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406, 409\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses only that the judge interviewed the child and that the controlling principle is the child’s welfare, but it does not say that the child’s preferences were considered, much less that they may be weighed more heavily as the child matures. There is no analysis or rule about considering a child’s wishes as a factor in the best‑interests test. The case therefore does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406, 409\u2.relevant_excerpt: "At the conclusion of the hearing, and after an interview with the child, the judge awarded custody of the child to the father and stepmother, with no rights of visitation by the mother. ... In Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930), we stated the basic rule applicable in such cases as follows: 'The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child.'"

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 402–03 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.proposition: The Court is also guided by the general policy that children should have “frequent and continuing contact” with both parents, when consistent with the child’s best interests.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly endorses the principle that the law values “frequent and continuing contact” of children with both parents, citing Felton v. Felton and In re Marriage of Murga. Although the court ultimately upholds reduced visitation based on the children’s best interests in this particular family situation, it clearly states the general policy favoring frequent and continuing contact with both parents when consistent with those best interests. Thus it supports the proposition as a general guiding policy, even while limiting it on these facts.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.relevant_excerpt: “The husband does argue, however, that it is most often preferred that both parents participate in the child rearing process and in the major decisions that attach thereto. We agree with the precept that ‘the law sees a value in “frequent and continuing contact” of the child[ren] with both . . . parents.’ Felton v. Felton, supra at 234, quoting from In re Marriage of Murga, 103 Cal. App. 3d 498, 503 (1980)… The ‘best interests’ principle requires that the narrow focus be on the interests of the child.”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: In addition, the Court may consider the extent to which each parent is willing and able to support the child’s relationship with the other parent. The court instead emphasizes the lack of material change in circumstances, the improper temporary custody order, and the mother’s continuing efforts to foster extended-family relationships.
